title: Did the Chinese invent the internet since they invented Fiber Optics? - Quora

response.answer_text: Did you read that article? In the 1960s at Standard Telecommunication Laboratories (STL) based in Harlow, Essex, England, Kao and his co-workers did their pioneering work in the realisation of fibre optics as a telecommunications medium, by demonstrating that the high-loss of existing fibre optics arose from impurities in the glass, rather than from an underlying problem with the technology itself. The key phrase from that citation is …existing fibre optics…. So no Mr. Kao and his team did not discover fiber optics, they very improved existing technology which allowed its usage in telecommunication. He very rightfully got Nobel price for his achievement. And no. Use of fiber optics in telecommunication does not mean invention of the Internet. Fiber optics is enabling technology for communication, any communication.

As has been mentioned, China didn’t invent Optical Fiber telecommunication. They also didn’t invent the Internet. It is the grandchild of ARPAnet, which was designed and built because at the time ALL the big universities wanted ARPA (Advanced Projects Research Agency) to buy them big computers, which even ARPA couldn’t have afforded. ARPAnet evolved into NSFnet. Eventually legislation was passed (at Al Gore’s sponsorship) to permit commercial network connections and the Internet was born. (This is a TERRIBLY condensed version of the story. If you want a fascinating read, check out: “Where Wizards Stay Up Late” by Katie Hafner.)
